docs.lead_paragraph: A libertarian author who has been called a white nationalist said college students who protested his guest lecture this week were "scary."

headline.main: Guest Lecturer Calls Protesting Students 'Seriously Scary'

docs.lead_paragraph: England captain Eoin Morgan blazed a fluent 107 to help secure a 45-run victory over West Indies in the first one-day international at a windy Sir Vivian Richards Stadium on Friday.

headline.print_headline: Morgan Ton Lifts England to Win Over West Indies in First ODI

docs.lead_paragraph: Johnson & Johnson said on Friday that a state court jury in Missouri had returned a verdict in its favor in the latest trial to arise out of thousands of lawsuits alleging the company's talc-based products can increase the risk of ovarian cancer.

headline.print_headline: Johnson & Johnson Wins Trial in Talc Product Liability Lawsuits
headline.main: Johnson & Johnson Wins Trial in Talc Product Liability Lawsuits

docs.lead_paragraph: Crews began restarting a power plant Friday at the base of Oroville Dam, allowing them to release water from the Northern California lake without having to send it over a badly damaged spillway, officials said.

headline.print_headline: Power Plant Restarted at California's Troubled Oroville Dam
headline.main: Power Plant Restarted at California's Troubled Oroville Dam

docs.lead_paragraph: The U.S. Federal Communications Commission is granting an emergency temporary waiver to Jewish community centers and telecommunications carriers that serve them to help track down callers who have made threats, the agency said on Friday.

headline.print_headline: FCC Approves Waivers to Track Jewish Center Threats
headline.main: FCC Approves Waivers to Track Jewish Center Threats

docs.snippet: The U.S. Federal Communications Commission is granting an emergency temporary waiver to Jewish community centers and telecommunications carriers that serve them to help track down callers who have made threats, the agency said on Friday....

docs.lead_paragraph: The state of Michigan appears increasingly unlikely to follow through on threats to close up to 38 chronically low-performing schools in Detroit and seven other cities this summer.
